Let me say to critics of the bill outside the Parliament that the Government will not in any way be competing with private enterprise by effecting insurance that private enterprise itself would wish to effect. No private trader need use this form of insurance unless he desires to do so. The bill also provides for the setting up of a corporation that will be as free as possible from ministerial direction.
- Why, it will be wholly controlled by the Minister.

- I direct the attention of the honorable member to clause 11, which shows the freedom of action that will be allowed to the corporation and the commissioner in carrying out the day-to-day business of export insurance. In reply to other criticisms that have been levelled against the bill, let me say that at all stages during its preparation private enterprise has been consulted, and that the private banks and the private insurance companies are in complete agreement with the policy that has been adopted by the Government. Private insurance companies did not want to enter this field for very obvious reasons, with which I shall deal in a moment. As ] have indicated, the bill seeks to help traders who wish to enter the export field. The honorable member for Lalor has also criticized the Government for the degree of risk that it is undertaking. By limiting the liability of the corporation to 85 per cent., the bill ensures that the private trader shall still have an incentive to help to recover any debts that may be owing to him. He will not be able, therefore, to sit back and to say that recovery of the debt is no longer his responsibility. The honorable member has also stated that, when Labour was in office, government-to-government trading with overseas countries was profitable, but he forgets that trading on that basis was carried out during the easy years after World War II. when Australia had for sale many goods that were in short supply overseas. How different it would find things to-day if it tried to adopt that policy! It would find the boot to be very much on the other foot.

speech.para: We are also confronted by the fact that trade with certain countries has been expanding. The Government has already

Export Payments Insurance [15 May, 1956.] Corporation Bill. 2055 endeavoured to help private enterprise to compete under such conditions, and by introducing this measure, it further seeks to help private enterprise to carry on in this modern world and not to destroy the initiative of those persons who are eager to help the nation. The bill is designed to cover a trader against the risk of insolvency on the part of overseas traders who desire to pay over a long period. Would-be Australian exporters often are able to operate only on irrevocable letters of credit, but, in the face of the fierce competition that is emerging, it is becoming increasingly necessary to offer longer terms of payment. No private insurance company could be expected to underwrite the risks that might be incurred over long periods. I remind the House that certain currencies suddenly become blocked, as happened in the case of Brazil only two years ago. Nations that traded with that country suddenly discovered that their payments were completely blocked.

talk.start.para: - They might be paid with counterfeit £5 notes.

- I hope that some day the honorable member may be paid in that way. If wo want to do business with our neighbouring countries, we must offer them longer terms. Certain risks are incurred in such trade and, accordingly, this Government must help traders. The greatest risk of all is that of blocked currencies. This measure will do more than anything else to help traders who want to offer long terms of payment, not expecting to be paid for, say, a year or eighteen months. No bank would cover individual Australian firms for such a long period. If the traders are able to obtain a guarantee from the Government that at least 85 per cent, of any debt incurred will be paid, the banks will be prepared to lend the extra sum of money that is required. In that way, therefore, business can go on and the banks will bo able to help the traders with their day today operations. We know of countries, particularly the United Kingdom and Canada, which have been trying to trade with South American countries, and of the problems they face if they have to operate without any form of governmental guarantee. We have seen it in Brazil and in the Argentine. If we have to deal with other socialist governments, then we must take certain steps to help our own private enterprise system. Fnally, then is the risk of war. No private insurance company can be expected to insure, or ever has insured against the risk of war. Yet if we desire to continue and to expand our overseas trade to-day, those risks may have to be incurred. Again, it is a corporation of this nature that can help in such difficult circumstances,

speech.para: I say to the Opposition that proof of the need for a corporation of this sort is to be found, first, in the United Kingdom from 1919, and then in Canada since 1948. But I should like to take issue with the honorable member for Lalor when he talks about the Canadian Government and the Canadian Corporation. I have been informed indefinitely that the Canadian Corporation does not deal with any type of insurance other than that proposed in this bill to be undertaken by the Australian corporation. It does not enter into the normal field of private enterprise insurance to any extent. I feel that, possibly, the honorable member for Lalor may have been slightly misinformed when he was dealing with this matter.

talk.start.para: - There is nothing in the act to prevent it.
- There is something in the act. The honorable member for Yarra (Mr. Cairns) will find it very definitely laid down.
- I was talking about the Canadian act.
- A corporation cannot enter into any business that is at present in the field of private enterprise.
- Certainly in this bill--
- The honorable member may have read the preamble to the bill. Possibly he has not got past the first page.
- I am talking about-
- Order ! The honorable member for Fawkner is making this speech. All the wisdom of the House does not reside in the honorable member for Yarra. He must remain silent.
- The honorable member for Fawkner needs some help.
- Order ! The honorable member will obey the Chair or he will go out. He has been continually interjecting.

- By establishing this corporation in a manner uniform with that undertaken in the United Kingdom and Canada, we shall be able to make use of such facilities and information on overseas traders that they already use, and that will be of immense benefit to us. In many cases in the last few years, the United Kingdom has taken over some of our export trade on our behalf because we have no corporation of this nature, as it has, and . we have lost a certain amount of our export trade. Now, with this corporation, we shall be able to enter this field in the same way as have the other nations. I can speak from some personal experience of the need for a body of this kind, chiefly at the other end, as it were, as an importer of machinery. We have found what great competition comes from those nations that have had corporations of this sort and have been able to guarantee long terms of payment, so that certain Group tries have been at an undue advantage in trying to do trade with this country. Extended credit such as will become available from a corporation of this sort has been the means of enabling a country like Western Germany to increase its exports to Australia, compared with other nations, and we have seen how it has benefited from the provisions of a bill of this nature.

speech.para: In international trade to-day, Australia is facing fierce competition. If we are dealing with other nations whose governments are supporting private enterprise extensively, then the Government of this country must do the same to help private firms. I believe, therefore, that this bill is a good first step towards the encouragement of exports. The encouragement of exports is, without any doubt, the most vital need for the whole of this Commonwealth to-day. I hope it will be only the first step of this Government, and that further positive steps will be taken to help our export trade. I spoke on this subject only a few weeks ago during the Address-in - Reply debate. The Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies), in September last year, referred to the United Kingdom habit of producing certain goods for export only and the help that that Government was able to give to exporting firms that followed that practice. I hope that it will not be long before we in Australia may also be able to encourage a similar scheme.

Secondly, we already encourage primary producers to export by the depreciation allowances that they are given in their day-to-day business. I am hoping that, if manufacturers indulge in and help our export trade, they will be allowed depreciation allowances on a similar basis. A committee dealt with the question of depreciation only a few months ago. This is one of the greatest ways in which manufacturers could be helped to increase their exports; I refer to an allowance of extra depreciation on those machines that were used to produce goods for export. The motor car spare parts industry is one that would benefit tremendously from a measure of that sort.

Thirdly, I believe that in a similar way to the United Kingdom practice, manufacturing enterprises could be helped to export by being given import licences for machinery. In this matter a great deal could be done to help manufacturers who guarantee minimum quotas of their production for export, in order to encourage them to the greatest extent.

As I have mentioned, our trade commissioner service should be expanded. I have heard that there is already a move to appoint local trade officers in certain parts of the world where full trade commissioner services would not be warranted. The United Kingdom has attached to the Board of Trade certain officers who are members of local chambers of commerce. They are resident in certain parts of the world and help trading between the United Kingdom and those countries. Australia could do a great deal by increasing services of that sort in order to help its manufacturers to export their goods.

More than anything else, the trade commissioner service could help with coordination as well as promotion and advertising of the goods of individual manufacturers in the smaller countries of the world with which at present we do very little business. They could also help in another way by the preparation of a general leaflet as a guide to exporters. In many ways it is at present possible for the Government and private enterprise to co-operate in this very great national need. "We support the principle of free trade, but as other nations now find that governments must increasingly help private manufacturers in their exports, either directly or indirectly, so also are we finding that it is necessary for us to do the same. This bill show3 how we can get the most out of government benevolence and individual initiative and how they may be combined in a constructive measure. Let us hope that this will be the forerunner of other constructive measures of S similar nature. Private enterprise will find this measure of very great help in its endeavours to expand exports. I hope that every would-be exporter will make use of this corporation at as early a date as possible.

talk.start.para: . - The Opposition regards this, measure as being a timid step in the right direction of encouraging Australia's export trade, which needs considerable encouragement because the whole pattern of our balance of payments has been thrown into discord by the vacillating policies that have been followed from time to time by the present Government. As my colleague, the honorable member for Lalor (Mr. Pollard), has indicated, we do not oppose this measure, but suggest that it does not go far enough in the fields that it has in view. In fact, it seemed obvious from the speech of the Minister for Trade (Mr. McEwen), on the 3rd May, that the Government was in a certain dilemma about the extension of Australia's import trade. He said that some exporters have not been able to meet their competitors' terms of sale in certain markets because of the payment risks involved, and the difficulties of financing sales on credit terms. In other words, he realized that one reason why Australia was not exporting -s much as it should export to markets that are potentially open was because Australian exporters were not in the same favorable position of being able to offer extended credit as were some exporters from such countries as the United States of America. It seems to this side of the House that this measure does little to remedy that deficiency to which the Minister pointed. Equally, it seems hard to imagine that there is, as some persons have indicated, available for Australian exporters about £25,000,000 worth of trade annually in which they have not participated in the past because of the absence of such a scheme as this.

speech.para: One or two newspapers stated, after this bill had been introduced - in fact, even before it was introduced - that it could be expected that, as a result of this measure, Australia's export trade might improve by about £25,000.000. The Minister did not indicate in what direction, or in what markets, these sales were to be sought, but he seemed to imply that the existence of this kind of scheme would stimulate trade to a considerable degree. Two examples have been cited of other countries where such schemes do operate. In Great Britain, the Export Credit Guarantee Department's history goes back nearly to 1919, and in Canada a scheme with a similar name has existed since 1944 or thereabouts. Statistics published in the brochures issued by the British Export Credit Guarantee Department indicate that in 1953 individual exporters numbering 3,500 used the facilities of the scheme, from which was financed trade worth about £400,000,000, or approximately one-seventh of Great Britain's total export trade. This is quite a significant proportion, which, if matched by Australia, would warrant the existence of such a scheme, but it seems to me that while the Australian measure is modelled on the experience of Great Britain and Canada, the Government has failed to provide in it the very real teeth which exist in the corresponding legislation of Great Britain and Canada. In both countries insurance is effected in respect of what they describe as risky trade. It seems to me to be doubtful whether Australia has not embarked on a great deal of this risky trade. The big gap that exists for Australian exporters is the lack of adequate credit facilities for export trade. I refer to such facilities as are found in America in an agency known as the Export Import Bank, which finances trade to the value of several hundreds of millions of dollars annually, in comparison with which the Australian example is puny.

talk.start.para: - The honorable member's complaint is that it is not big enough ?

- No. I am suggesting that it does not reach down to the roots of the difficulties that face the Australian exporter in certain markets, particularly in the Asian countries adjacent to us. Those countries would be willing to take exports of a capital nature such as have been suggested here, and the real risk is not a political one for Australia. It is not a risk, for instance, that the Indonesian Government will run short of sterling or that there are likely to be violent revaluations of its own currency in terms of ours. What is lacking is provision to meet potential importers in such countries who may say to Australia, "We give you this order. to the value of £1,000,000 for certain equipment, but we are not in a position to pay, except over a term of three, four, or more years ". Apparently, in order to encourage this kind of trade, an organization has been established which seems to me to cover only short-term activities. If such markets do exist, and this scheme encourages them, well and good, but looking at the matter with a longer view, it seems that this is not the real gap in the pattern of Australia's expanding trade, and that this measure does not go far enough in the directions in which it ought to go. That is the first stricture which we place upon this measure. The examples of Great Britain and Canada have been cited with approval, but the important sections of the relevant acts in those countries have been overlooked. One of my colleagues will discuss that matter at greater length later. In each of those acts there are two parts, devoted to short-term transactions and long-term transactions. I do not know whether the bill before us is sufficiently loosely drafted to make it capable of embracing both types of transactions. The Minister did not indicate anything of that kind in his speech. In fact, I suggest that his speech was deliberately vague abou the possible application and implications of the measure. Some people have suggested that trade worth £25,000,000 annually is there for the taking, but the Minister gave not a single example to show where it existed or what our likely markets were. The only specific instances that he gave were in relation to the marketing boards, which were cited by my colleague. They seem to present an entirely different kind of problem because in Australia marketing boards are in the nature of Government organizations. Negotiations tend to be conducted on a government-to-government, rather than on a private-trader-to-private-trader basis. That matter could be dealt with in an entirely different measure.

speech.para: Those who support this scheme have claimed that its mere existence is likely to make the banker more ready to extend credit. That would seem to indicate a lamentable attitude on the part of both the Government and banks, lt seems that a system has been condoned under which bankers can be induced to underwrite trade only if there are what are called "very limited risks". It has been suggested that the bill covers not ordinary commercial risks, but risks of an extraordinary, and mainly political, kind associated with war, exchange problems, currency revaluation and so on. It is said that the banks have not encouraged certain trade because no such scheme has existed. That is an indictment of business as we understand it in Australia. We are told that the inducement of a small premium will make all the difference. In Canada the premium rate is $ per cent, or 15s. per £100 of trade. In Great Britain the figure is lower for certain kinds of activity and higher for others, but the average is of the order of Ils. per £100 of trade. Is it seriously said that for several years past Australian export trade to the tune of £25,000,000 has languished merely because there has not been in existence a fund of £250,000 - an amount representing less than 1 per cent, of the value of the transactions involved? Is that suggestion seriously made by the defenders of the scheme? If that kind of jiggery-pokery is needed in order to stimulate trade it is a sad commentary on public affairs.

Labour is anxious to encourage any practical move to expand our export trade because the volume of our exports is the criterion for the volume of goods and services that we are able to import. Ithas been said all around the House, and particularly on the Government side, that if Australia is to develop we must have more and more imports, yet this pussyfooting kind of measure is put before us as though it were the thing for which the Australian nation had been waiting for years. It does not seem to me to deal with the basic problem at all. What is needed is not to be found in this bill. There should be assistance, perhaps on a bigger scale than is contemplated in the bill, for the long-term type of venture, [n Great Britain this has been recognized as the direction in which the stimulus is needed. Mr. Robert Owen, a member of the Export Credits Guarantee Department of Great Britain, spoke on the subject to the Glasgow Chamber of Commerce in December, 1955. He is reported in The Times Weekly Review, a survey of banking and insurance, on Thursday, the 16th February, 1956, as having said -

quote.para: What we therefore seek to do is to enable the insured exporter, in conditions of security, to offer such credit terms as are current and justifiable. I believe that this is where our duty to the export trade lies. We are of course much preoccupied with what other countries are doing; were wo to assist in holding down terms offered from the United Kingdom to a point where our oversea competitors offered longer credit and scooped the kitty in consequence, we should lie acting against the interests of our export trade. We must not do that.

speech.para: I would suggest that, equally, we must not fall into the trap that has been clearly seen by the people on the other side of the world. Our inability to compete on some overseas markets is not due entirely to high costs. To some members of this House, of course, high costs mean only high wages, but if they have listened to what has been said by my colleagues this afternoon they will realize that high profits are just as important. Other countries can compete against us because of better credit facilities alone. An overseas firm may wish to buy an Australian article on the score of cost, but it may be pi-evented from doing so because the Australian exporter cannot give credit terms to compare with those offered by Canada. Great Britain, and the United States of America. The Government should give serious consideration to that very real gap in our trading arrangements.

From time to time there is much talk of what is called the " cold war To-day the emphasis in the " cold war " seems to be shifting from military assistance to economic assistance through the aiding of export trade in the way suggested in the bill. I should like to refer honorable members to an article that appeared on Sunday the 15th April, 1956, in the New York Times Weekly Review, which by no means could be considered a radical journal. The article, which is headed. " Russia Steps Out as World Trader - Soviet is telling Europeans that she can supply their needs in the future " was written by Mr. Michael L. Hoffman, a well-known expert in this field. He indicates that Russia is offering some of the Asian countries much-needed food and equipment. It is also offering to take certain goods off their hands in exchange for goods that they need. Moreover,, these offers have found a very receptive audience in Asian countries. I suggest that a more ambitious approach such as that should be undertaken by this Government, even if only on the selfish ground of future security. Surely we are entitled to adopt that attitude. The challenge is there. This great country of Russia has reached a stage of economic development where it can offer economic assistance to countries that we regard as near neighbours. If we fail to give assistance of this kind the iron curtain countries will step in and fill the vacuum. I suggest that modern forces tolerate a vacuum no more than nature does. If we do not fill that vacuum by means of economic aid, as I feel that we are in the position to do, somebody else will do it, perhaps by a means that it less economically desirable and which may possibly be unfortunate for us in the future. That is another count on which we criticize this measure. As I have said, it is a timid measure which ought to be a visionary, ambitious and expansive measure.

The problem - to expand our trade both with our present customers and with those countries in which we have not yet developed markets - is a real one. The insurance field to which the bill relates is not normally occupied by commercial enterprise. In fact, the Canadians regard it as one that private enterprise cannot fill; a government agency is in a position, by means of its diplomatic and trade relations with other parts of the world, to do this thing on a far cheaper basis than if it were done by commercial enterprise. Honorable members on this side of the House see no harm in permitting this new corporation to have power to engage in marine, fire and other types of insurance on behalf of those customers who want to give their business to it. If people do not wish to insure with the corporation, they need not do so; but if they do wish to insure with it, we should make it possible for them to get the best terms from it.

Let us provide the public with the choice of insuring with a private company or the government corporation when they wish to obtain cover against what are called the commercial kinds of risk. Let the Government admit that that is not a field only for private concerns, and give the corporation a chance to expand to other 'fields in the same way as the joint venture that operates in the United Kingdom, where the approved exporter, in co-operation with the corporation, engages in transactions on the basis, not of an 85 per cent, guarantee, but on the basis of a 50-50 guarantee in a joint venture. Again, this timid measure does not provide for that kind of tiling. I suggest that it is in the kind of market in which we have to advertise and develop new contacts that we are more likely to find this field; not in the area, where an 85 per cent, cover is guaranteed if the insurance policy should fall in, but in some of those areas where one needs the enterprise that these people are so prone to talk about from time to time.

An amendment to the bill will be proposed along those lines. Another amendment will suggest that the scope of the corporation should be broadened in order to give it what we call the teeth that are possessed by the corporations in Canada and the United Kingdom. Meanwhile, we give the measure our blessing for what it is, a timid step in a very necessary direction.

talk.start.para: .- I think that we can always rely on the honorable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr. Crean) to adopt a reasonable approach to any measure that comes before this House. But I find that he has really a hazy idea of the bill as it was introduced. He said that there was an impression abroad that the bill would encourage trade to the extent of £25,000,000. Those who have read the bill will hasten to assure the honorable member for Melbourne Ports that the sum of £25,000,000 is a limit to which the insurance corporation-
- That figure was quoted from a daily paper. I am not confused on that point.

- The honorable member must appreciate that £25,000,000 is the limit of the risk that the Government corporation can undertake. Surely, the honorable member would not subscribe to the introduction of any measure without a limit being placed on the extent of the risks that it could undertake. The honorable member went on to talk about the type of risk which this insurance corporation would undertake, and said that there was very little likelihood of a country's failure to pay. May I remind the honorable member of the situation which arose in Brazil, in 1952, when that country blocked its sterling currency and people who had exported to Brazil were unable to secure payment for their exports? I suggest that that eventuality will be covered by the hill. May I also draw the honorable member's attention to. the fact that he said that the bill was designed to cover revaluation of currency? The bill does nothing of the sort. There is no mention of cover for the revaluation of currency either in the second-reading speech of the Minister' for Trade (Mr. McEwen) or in the bill itself. I quote from the second-reading speech of the Minister, as follows : -

quote.para: It is proposed to provide insurance, broadly, against the risk of non-payment whether arising from causes such as insolvency of the overseas -buyer or his failure to pay within a certain period, or from actions at overseas governments such as blockage of foreign exchange or the sudden imposition of new import controls in markets abroad.

speech.para: Secondly, the honorable member was not very secure in his grounds for debating this bill because he has not a knowledge of the situation. I say that his objection, which he stated very broadly, is that the bill is not radical enough for the Opposition, which considers that it should cover additional risks, including marine, fire and other forms of insurance. I believe that that is an inherent risk in this bill to those of us who believe in the system of free enterprise.

The other speaker from the Opposition, the honorable member for Lalor (Mr. Pollard), discussed this bill with a degree of mental reservation, the reason for which is not hard to find. I think that he damned the bill with faint praise. When we look for the reason, we find that, in 1946, a Mr. Dedman, well known for his socialist tendencies, endeavoured to promote this type of insurance, but he found that it was not acceptable to the commercial world. At that time, either the type of insurance was not required, or there was a genuine mistrust of Mr. Dedman and the brand of socialism that he represented.

talk.start.para: - There was no competition then.

- I have already covered that eventuality, as the honorable member would know if he had followed my remarks, but he lives in a world apart. I said that at that time either the type of insurance was not required or there was genuine mistrust of the socialists. Naturally enough, if the insurance was not required, it was, firstly, because there was no competition and, secondly, because there was ample opportunity to sell goods. Consequently, this particular kind of insurance was not desired by manufacturers. But, if, in 1946, this insurance scheme was promoted by this arch socialist, Dedman, there would arise that mistrust. A mistrust, Mr. Acting Deputy Speaker, that would, I suggest, be shared by you and any other male in this community, since that gentleman even went to the extreme of removing the tails from our shirts, banned Father Christmas and pink icing, and performed various other high-minded acts of statesmanship. There may arise an uneasy feeling in regard to this measure that if this is the same as Mr. Dedman's idea then it is diluted socialism, which may be harmless, but useful, in the hands of a Liberal party government, but dangerous if left in the hands of a socialist government.
- There will be no cake this Christmas.

- Well, that represents a very serious problem for the honorable member, and all I can say is that if he has not a cook who can bake a cake he should come to our place and we will get him one. Now, Mr. Acting Deputy Speaker, this bill is novel in its approach as applied to Australian conditions, and it may appear somewhat revolutionary to those who view with trepidation the. Government's entry into the fields of business and commerce. The first reaction one might have is that the Government has sufficient bother of its own in the sphere of government without going into the insurance business. One immediately asks what experience the Government has to enable it to conduct this type of insurance, which will deal particularly with foreign credit, and whether or not this class of business should be left in the hands of private enterprise. I am assured, however, that this bill represents a plan for government-sponsored and governmentfinanced insurance, and does not mean the intrusion of the Government into the normal province of private insurance companies.
- I will bet that the honorable member has been assured of that.

- I know that the honorable member for Yarra (Mr. Cairns) believes himself to be an economist of great distinction, and thinks that Providence has sent him here to give some indications of what economy is, and of the practice of economy, to the less fortunate members of his own party, but I assure the honorable member that in my view there is an exportable surplus of economists, and possibly he may find himself in a draft to go out of this country. I do not think that even if he subscribed the 85 per cent, that this bill envisages he would get a company to underwrite him. Prom the inquiries I have made I find that the type of risk to be covered under the bill is normally not undertaken by private insurance companies. The bill, therefore, seeks, I hope, to provide cover by the Government only of risks that would not normally be covered by private enterprise. That is the basic difference between my views as a subscriber to the principle of free enterprise and those of honorable gentlemen opposite who subscribe to socialism. Eire and marine insurance, for instance, may be accepted as covering goods against physical damage, but the form of export insurance provided for in the bill is designed to cover the insurer against non-payment by the buyer, or by the buyer's country. Consequently, I accept the bill as a constructive measure, but I hasten to add that skilful administration will be required to make a success of the undertaking. As well as being constructive, the bill offers a service, or facility, not avails able at the present time. There is inherent in it, however, the danger that the very introduction of this kind of insurance, as I have indicated, may lend itself, in the future, as a means by which a socialist-minded government could enter the existing insurance field. It would appear, on the surface, that the likelihood of that will be made perfectly clear by the amendments to be moved at a later stage by the Opposition; hut I am glad to see that every precaution has been taken in the bill to guard against the eventuality I have mentioned. Viewing this matter with realism, however, one must accept the fact that such precautions in the preamble of the bill and elsewhere in it would not be worth the paper on which they are printed if a socialist government wished to use an existing orsra.niza.tion for the purpose of entering other insurance fields.

speech.para: The other immediate question which poses itself is whether or not the bil will set up another government department, with numerous secretaries, secretaries of secretaries, typists of secretaries of secretaries, and under-secretaries - in short, all the people apparently required by a government department to enable an organization to function. But in this regard I have been enheartened to read a report that a similar insurance organization in Canada requires a minimum of staff to administer it. I hope that our Australian experience will be similar in that respect. The first requisite for the success of the corporation would, in my opinion, be the appointment of the right man as commissioner. He would need to be an experienced man. As I see it, the position calls for many qualities. The commissioner will need to be a diplomat who is a specialist at one and the same time in foreign affairs and a master also of the problems of insurance, banking and foreign exchange. If the right man is available I think the Government should not quibble at paying him an adequate salary. However, there is another immediate difficulty in the appointment of a commissioner. As this kind of business is new to Australia it may be difficult to find an Australian with the necessary qualifications.

talk.start.para: - Tut, tut!
- Oh, I acknowledge that the honorable member for Yarra would be a suitable appointment, but others may not share that view with me. 11 r. Cairns interjecting,
- Order! The honorable member for Yarra will cease interjecting, or I shall ask him to retire from the chamber. He has been warned before.

- He is quite harmless. The commissioner will require to be a man of Australian outlook, and in that regard the honorable member for Yarra will be a lamentable failure. I repeat that we should want a commissioner with an Australian outlook. To put it bluntly, what we are trying to do is to improve our export position as against other countries which are competing in the same market, and it so happens that- some of the competitors with whom we must contest our overseas markets are not only British dominions, but, in respect of some commodities, Great Britain itself; so, if we must bring a commissioner from outside with experience in these matters, I suggest that we should immediately begin to train an Australian to take over the position, and that he be installed in it as soon as he is trained for it.

speech.para: I pass from that situation to the preparation that has preceded the introduction of this measure. I am sure that in the preparation of the measure we have had the advantage of the experience of similar schemes operating in Great Britain, Canada and elsewhere. These operations have been successful, and it should follow that most of the pitfalls have been guarded against in this measure as far as possible. However, it is obvious that great skill will be required in selecting the risks to be covered and in fixing the premiums to be charged. The premiums must not be so high as to load an already high cost of production with another burden. It is absolutely essential that no compulsion should, be applied to insurers to insure, yet it is essential if the venture is to be profitable, that good as well as bad risks should be covered. The inevitable tendency will bc for bad risks to seek cover while the good ones hold aloof. Securing the right spread of business Will be quite an art, and, as I have said, it will call for the experience of a highly qualified man.

As I see it, one of the great dangers of the measure is that the fund may be subjected to continual pressure from people who want to engage in wild-cat export schemes at the taxpayers' risk. This has been guarded against, partly, hy the provision that the exporter must bear a. minimum of 15 per cent, of the risk involved, but I hope that, in the great majority of transactions, he will bo required to bear more than this percentage. This will ensure that the exporter engages only in business that he considers sound. However, as I have indicated, the Teal safeguard is to have a commissioner of capacity and one who is free from political pressure. The Minister is to he congratulated on the pains he has taken to prevent ministerial direction of any individual transaction and to restrict his own functions to the laying down of general lines of policy. I have no doubt that, under the administration of the present Minister, the commissioner would be left free from pressure anyway, but what would happen under a socialist administration is not pleasant to contemplate.

The bill itself does not indicate the estimated revenue and the probable, or possible, loss or profit. This is a new field of activity, and I think it would have been prudent to indicate what the establishment expenses were expected to be. We have had one sad experience with the Australian Aluminium Production Commission, with which the Government entered the commercial field without a full appreciation of the dangers and difficulties ahead. To all appearances, the volume of business of the corporation will be small in the initial stages. I expect that, even with the best of commissioners and the best of administration, losses will be incurred. We must prepare our minds for that contingency. It is hardly likely that the venture will make high profits, and, in fact, it is indicated in the bill that it is proposed to steer the rather difficult course of making neither profits nor losses. I suggest that this is certainly a rather difficult course, but, if the corporation pays its way, we shall be very fortunate indeed. If the losses are small, and the stimulus to exports is great, the effort will have been worth while for the future. As I have said - I think it should be stated again and again, so that there shall be no misapprehension about it - the corporation will provide insurance against political risks and actions in other countries. That is one reason why this class of business may be particularly suited to government operations. It offers a great chance for the chain of trade commissioners that we have already established abroad to show their usefulness and their effectiveness by giving an accurate and fast news service telling of the risks involved in the countries where they are stationed. The honorable member for Fawkner (Mr. Howson). I think, referred to that matter a short time «go.

This measure should receive the support of manufacturers' organizations, which must see in it a means of improving the export situation. Yet this measure alone will not solve the problem of exports. "When goods were easy to sell, no one wanted this type of insurance, but, now that prices are becoming highly competitive, new markets are being sought. This bill is not the cure-all for our export problems and worries. The solution of those problems depends on the reduction of costs of production, which themselves depend on efficient management and the will of factory employees to produce goods at costs that will enable U3 to compete with overseas prices. It is interesting to note that the "Minister stated, in his second-reading speech, that he had discussed this type of insurance with representatives of various sections of the community such as exporters, marketing boards, manufacturers, primary producers and banking and insurance interests. He stated that all these representatives were favorably disposed towards the proposal, and he added that the Government looked confidently for the co-operation of the banking system in the day-to-day operations of the export payments insurance corporation. May I say, in passing, that it is strange that the Government looks confidently to the banking institutions when it needs their support. I am sure that, in this matter, the banks will give their ready cooperation, even though I feel that our private banking system has not always received the best of co-operation from the Government. However, that is another question. Suffice it to say that I believe the measure will receive the approval and approbation of those engaged in commerce and industry. This is more than the previous Labour socialist administration could command. The proposals envisaged in the bill merit a trial, and therefore I commend it to the House.

talk.start.para: .The honorable member for Mitchell (Mr. Wheeler), who has just resumed his seat, said that the type of risk entailed in currency revaluation was not covered by the bill. In other words, he said that it does not cover the loss that an exporter may sustain through revaluation or any adjustment of the exchange rate. The honorable member's statement is borne out by the observations made by the Minister for Trade (Mr. McEwen) at page 4 of the roneod copy of his second-reading speech. However, clause 13 of the bill makes no express provision in this matter, nor can it be taken by inference that it does not cover this type of loss. On my reading of the clause, the honorable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr. Crean) was correct when he said that this loss is covered and that, therefore, the provisions of the bill are contrary to the express intention of the Minister as stated in his second-reading speech. I wish to mention also the affirmation of the honorable member for Mitchell that the insurance business provided for in this measure is a type of business that private enterprise does not desire to undertake, and that, therefore, it must be undertaken by the Government. Why is this so? Although the honorable member, on the one hand, denounces anything that smacks of socialism, he condones and approves, by implication, and even by express statement, legislation that smacks of socialism. When it comes. to a matter of private profit, as opposed to national interest, Government supporters unanimously favour the right to make private profits regardless of the effect upon the national economy. That remains uncontroverted by honorable members opposite. In fact, it has been confirmed that, when faced with a choice, they prefer private profit to the national interest.

speech.para: I agree with what the honorable member for Melbourne Ports has said about the bill. It is true that we support it, but we support it with the reservation that it seems to us that the Minister, in mid-winter garb, has placed his toe gingerly in the water, but has not- taken the plunge. Metaphorically speaking, he has put his toe in the water of assisting the export trade, but has gone no further. His approach to the whole matter is reflected in the bill itself, which is circumscribed and very limited. Tt does not touch the basis of the problems and difficulties which confront our export trade to-day. It may be fairly said that the Minister's approach to this matter, as well as to other matters of trade, lacks vision. In that regard, he is supported by honorable members opposite. It is obvious from the statements in regard to trade that the Minister has made from time to time that he is going to take bold and aggressive action of a kind of which nobody in his right senses would approve. In the issue of the Financial Review dated the 10th May, we read in black headlines -

quote.para: Trade drive gathering way. Assault planned on U.K. policy.

speech.para: The Minister advocates an adjustment of the Ottawa preferences in favour of Australia, despite the objection by the United Kingdom under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, yet in the very same speech he refers at various times to the system of subsidies and stabilization of markets at home, which must, in the long run, have an effect upon our exports. It is the very thing for which he criticizes adversely the nation which has done more than any other country in the world to foster Australia as a nation.

I suggest that a greater realization of the fact that we are faced with a competitive buyers' market would radically alter, along the lines indicated by the honorable member for Lalor (Mr. Pollard) and the honorable member for Melbourne Ports, the approach to this matter by the Minister and other honorable members opposite. The sooner we adjust our thinking to meet the conditions of a. competitive buyers' market, the sooner will we produce something here that will be of real benefit, not only to individual exporters and manufacturers, but also to all exporters of primary products. That will be of benefit te the nation as a whole. It is only by our ability to compete in the markets of the world that we shall be able to solve the problem of our adverse trade balance. The suggestions by the honorable member for Mitchell and other honorable members opposite that we should reduce our present standards of living and conditions of labour in this country in order to compete with the Japanese, with their sub-standard conditions-

talk.start.para: - I rise to order. I did not say that. I should be glad if the honorable member would withdraw that remark. *

speech.para: Mr. ACTING DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr. Lawrence). - No point of order is involved. The honorable member may make a personal explanation later, if he so desires.

talk.start.para: - If the honorable member for Mitchell did not say that expressly, I withdraw my statement. By implication, insofar as he referred to the high cost of labour in this country in comparison with other countries, the honorable member is in favour of reducing our labour costs. If he is not in favour of reducing our labour costs, and if he believes that we should maintain the present conditions of labour in Australia, I shall be very glad to have his assurance on that score.

speech.para: This measure meets some, not all, of the requirements of the' situation. It is designed to cover certain losses, lt must be aimed at trade of a type which, apparently, we have not engaged in hitherto, because of the possible losses involved. When we look at our present trading balances with the nations with which we do the greatest volume of trade, can we say that there is any great risk involved there? Can we say that there is any great risk involved in our trade with New Zealand, the United Kingdom and the other countries with which normally we do business? Obviously the answer is that we cannot. Therefore,. this legislation must be designed to cover trade of a type which hitherto has not been carried on to any great extent. The Minister has emphasized in his, secondheading speech that the object of the measures is to increase trade. The article to which the honorable member for Melbourne Ports and the honorable member for Micthell referred appeared in the Canberra Times of the 1st March, 1956. It began as follows : -

quote.para: Big Rise in Exports Likely from Credits Plan.
Trade authorities estimate that the proposed exports credit insurance scheme will increase Australia's export earnings by at least £25,000,000 in the first year of operation.

speech.para: The article went on to state what the Minister for Trade hoped to do and when he hoped that the legislation would be passed. Such optimism is not borne out by the" facts. Our trade with our normal customers does not necessitate this kind of insurance. It is only when we consider the kind of trade that we could develop with our neighbours in the Near-East and with countries in the Middle East that we see a very limited need for legislation such as this. If the amendments foreshadowed by the honorable member for Lalor were adopted, they would have the effect of increasing the scope of the bill considerably, and it would be possible that, within the next few years, we should be able to improve our trade to the extent of the £25,000,000 mentioned in the Canberra Time*. But that will happen only if the amendments are carried.

Before that improvement can be made, we shall have to do a lot of pioneering work which, obviously, because it will not be profitable - our friends opposite stand self-condemned -in this regard - private enterprise will not handle. So that pioneering work will have to be done by the Government, in the national interest, as opposed to a selfish personal interest. I refer to the development of our trade with the Middle East, South-East Asia and the Far East - or the Near East, as we know it.

Does this bill cover those cases? I submit that it does not. The Government recognizes, obviously, that there is some national aspect of the objectives which the measure is designed to achieve. The honorable member for Mitchell has mentioned the Brazilian transfer difficulties which cost the United Kingdom Government £3,500,000. We find that, according to the United Kingdom trading accounts and balance-sheets for 1954, under the special guarantee scheme, the accumulated balance at the end of that year was a debit balance of about £8,000. The next year's trading resulted in a surplus of approximately £304,000, so the cumulative balance at the end of that year was a credit balance of £296,000. The deficit of approximately £1,500,000 in 1954 was wiped out, and at the commencement of the next financial year there was a small credit balance. With regard to the total schemes covered by the British legislation, the revenue has exceeded the outgoings, but the British legislation covers a number of types of insurance guarantees which, apparently, this bill does not cover. The type of insurance to which the United Kingdom and Canadian acts refer is, in my opinion, not envisaged in this bill, otherwise express provision would need to have been made for it. For the corporation to take powers in regard to the determination of the type of policies that it will grant without express authority to do so would be ultra vires. Therefore, express provision should be made in the bill to cover the types of insurance that exist under the United Kingdom scheme, and to which I shall refer later.

Such schemes are not new, Britain has had a form of insurance since the turn of the century. Canada, Sweden, Germany, Holland, Belgium and France all have such schemes, but, significantly, the United States of America has not one. [ shall deal now with the position in the United States, because it deserves special consideration. The honorable member for Melbourne Ports has mentioned the operations of the export credit guarantee system in that country, an extension of which to this country will be sought in an amendment to be moved by the honorable member for Lalor. Those functions are dicharged by the Export- Import Bank. Appendices to the bank's latest report, which covers the period January to June, 1955, indicate that loans that have been guaranteed to foreign importers to enable them to take advantage of the offer of American imports to cover such things as highway construction, buses, railroad spare parts, construction for grain storage, construction of canals in India, dams and the production of manganese ore. Insurance coverage for numerous other things is further evidence of our inability to compete recently for the supply . of farm equipment to the Indonesian Government. Because we were unable to give competitive terms, we failed to obtain a large contract amounting to - I speak subject to correction - approximately £3,500,000 for the supply of agricultural plant and equipment. Our exporters could have coped with such a transaction if we had been able to give them the necessary facilities. The assistance that members of the Opposition have in mind would be designed to give, not only a safer guarantee on existing trade with other countries in regard to consumer goods and possibly some services, but also a system of guarantee, with adequate credit support, to foster, encourage and open up new markets for services and exports of manufactured goods and also exports of primary products.

Let me refer briefly to the position that obtains in the United Kingdom. The United Kingdom found that, on a national basis, there were certain considerations which it was desirable to include in the exports credit guarantee legislation. Accordingly, amending legislation was introduced in 1949, sub-section 1 (1.) of which provides -

quote.para: For the purposes of encouraging trade with places outside the TJ.K., the Board of Trade, -after consultation with the Advisory Council, may, with the consent of the Treasury, make arrangements for giving guarantees to, or for the benefit of, persons carrying on business in the U.K., being guarantees in connexion with the export, manufacture, treatment, and distribution of goods, the rendering of services, «or any other matter which appears to the Board" of Trade conducive to the said purpose.

speech.para: Sub-section 2 (1.) provides -

quote.para: For the purposes specified in sub-section (1.) of section 1, or for the purpose of rendering economic assistance to countries outside the U.K., the Board of Trade, may, with the consent of the Treasury, make arrangements for the giving of guarantees to, or for the benefit of, persons carrying on business in the U.K. as appears to the Board to be expedient -

speech.para: And these are the operative words - in the national interest.

That is one of the facets of the United Kingdom act which will lead Opposition members to move an amendment to make the corporation capable of carrying out a national job as opposed to such a timid, petty, and short-sighted objective as was indicated by the Minister in his second-reading speech.

The British Board of Trade and the Export Credit Guarantee Department found that they could use that piece of legislation as a means to encourage a particular type of trade which it was desired, in the national interest, to encourage. I refer particularly to trade with the dollar areas as represented by the United States. Canada and Latin America. To do that, it ti as found that the English exporters required a particular type of policy which they called a joint venture policy. Under the joint venture policy, 50 per cent, of the risk was accepted by the United Kingdom

Government. The joint venture schemes made provision for services in the nature of advertising campaigns in the importing country, the very real cost of which had to be borne by the exporter immediately he signed the contract. To enable him to sign the contract it was necessary for him to have some assurance of the assistance that he would receive towards financing a considerable outlay in the initial stage. Such a provision in the United Kingdom or in Australia, as the case may be, would mean that the exporter would have to forgo a relatively safe home market that he had been exploiting in the past, and put all his eggs in one basket. In order to encourage export trade with the dollar areas, it was found necessary to jack up the type of insurance granted under the British scheme, and for that reason, as I have indicated, the act was amended in 1949. Similar amendments should bf included in this bill.

The Canadian scheme has a similar provision. The Canadian corporation consists of the Minister of Finance and the Minister of Trade and one other member. The relevant provision, which is contained in Part II. of the Canadian Act of 1903 has not been applied since 1948, simply because that function has been taken over by the Canadian Bank which acts, in relation to export credit guarantees, in a manner similar to that of the Export - Import bank at Washington. The Canadian act makes provision whereby payment for the goods by the importer is guaranteed by the exporting government in an endeavour to foster trade on new markets. Section 22 of that act provides, amongst other things, thai; -

quote.para: The Governor-in-Council on the recommendation of the Ministers of Finance and Trade and Customs may authorize the Finance Minister to -

item.label: (a)
item.para: guarantee the obligation of any foreign government or its agent, to pay for Canadian produced goods,
make a loan to such a government to pay for the Canadian produced goods,

item.label: (c)
item.para: purchase or acquire for value any securities laid down by such a government in support of the contract - if the government of such other country requests such a guarantee and undertakes to indemnify the Canadian Government against loss under such a guarantee.

talk.start.para: - There is real substance in that provision.

- I agree with the honorable member for Lalor. He himself has pointed out the reality of the substance. The accent in this debate so far has been on manufactured goods, and services. If a provision such as this were included in the bill, it would guarantee some means of facilitating the export of primary products. The primary industries would benefit immeasurably, as pointed out by the honorable member for Lalor, and we would be able to compete on more than adequate grounds with the trend in Russian trade policy. Recently, the Russians made a deal with Burma, and took Burma's surplus rice off its hands. Russia has been able also to lend in the vicinity of 90,000,000 dollars to the Indian Government at 2£ per cent, interest for the purpose of building a 1,000,000 tons steel plant. There are canals and dams and other developmental projects in the Near East that are closer to us than to America, which we could exploit if we had provisions such as this in the bill. There are schemes for the export of our productive machinery that would help the backward nations to produce food for themselves. In the history of the world there has never been over-production ; there has always been under-consumption.

speech.para: As far as the amendment is concerned, provision will also be made to assist in the disposal of our surplus goods by the granting of, long-term credits to the importing nation. There is nothing improper about this method. The Minister, in his speech, suggested that we were using unfair tactics to dispose of our surplus goods. There is nothing unfair in this. It is normal business whereby we, as a nation, are financing the importer to buy our goods and we are guaranteeing our exporter against non-payment if he is prepared to grant terms with government assistance to the importer of our primary or secondary products. They are items that we desire to export. Such a measure, as amended, would have the support of all sections of the community. These contracts would be based on national interest, and being so based, they would benefit not only the exporter, the grower and the manufacturers, but all the people who handled those goods right down to the waterside worker, who really has the final handling of them physically on this side of the contract.

We could deal adequately with Russian competition under such an amendment. We must be prepared to go the whole way, to take our courage in our hands and not be timid about a matter of this nature. We should be able to grant extended terms of credit in competition with others in that field of exports, and we would be facilitating the means of overcoming our adverse balance of trade. Nationally, the job that this bill would be capable of performing would be of great magnitude. The nation as a whole, and not merely the individual exporter and those who grow or manufacture the exports, would benefit. If we do not approach the whole subject, including the operation of this bill, from a national viewpoint as opposed to a very limited type of insurance on our consumer goods - the things that we normally export - then no good purpose will be served by the bill other than to finance a few, perhaps, risky ventures which may not turn out to be risky once that particular channel of trade has been established.

If we approach this matter with vision, imagination and boldness, we shall find that we can open up new markets competitively, and get rid of our food surplus. We could finance the winning of specialized types of trade and help develop the Asian nations, which are nearest to us and which are the ones with whom we should logically trade, taking into account such things as freight and the normal risks entailed in business. It is for that reason that we urge the Government, particularly the honorable members of the Australian Country party, to take a second look at this bill, and to see just what substance there is in the amendment from the point of view of encouraging the export of primary products.

talk.start.para: - What is the amendment? '
- The amendment is based on the Canadian act. Perhaps the honorable member was not listening.

talker.name: ADERMANN, Charles
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr C F Adermann

talk.start.para: - Order! The honorable member's time has expired.

.- I rise to support this measure because I was first to mention it in this House more than eighteen months ago. I remember very well when the original announcement was made by the Government just prior to the 1954 election that such a measure would be introduced. As everybody knows, the investigations that have had to be made, and other details, have caused the introduction of the bill to be delayed until now.

speech.para: Before dealing with the measure generally, I should like to have something to say about the interjections of the honorable member for Yarra (Mr. Cairns) when my colleague the honorable member for Fawkner (Mr. Howson) was speaking. My colleague mentioned theCanadian act, and you will recall, Mr. Deputy Speaker, that you had to call the honorable member for Yarra, to order because he kept interjecting in respect of the Canadian act. I have taken the opportunity to have a look at the Canadian act, and I have no doubt that the honorable member for Yarra has done likewise. The real purpose of the act is covered on page 5, chapter 105, section. 13 of the Export Credits Insurance Act. I am quite prepared to admit that that portion could lead one to believe that the Canadian Export Insurance Corporation could enter into any kind of insurance. But as we read through section 13 we find at the end of sub-section (2.) that we are referred to the 1944-45 act, chapter 39, section 13.

If we take the trouble to look at that section, we find that it reads in practically the same way as does the 1952 act, but it describes the word " loss ". The_ 1952 act says that the corporation may insure an exporter against any risk of loss in connexion with the export- and so on. When we look at a definition of the word " loss ", we find the following : -

quote.para: In this section "loss" means loss accruing to an exporter upon non-payment, when due, of the purchase price of goods exported, by reason of insolvency or 'delay of the importer or his inability to secure the currency with which the purchase price is to be paid. 1

speech.para: That section precludes the corporation from entering into all types of insurance, as the honorable member for Yarra would have had us believe by his interjections during the speech of my colleague the honorable member for Fawkner. I feel quite sure that if the investigation made by the Government and its departmental officers over the period that this matter has been in their minds, showed it was possible to insure any ordinary business, as, according to the honorable member for Yarra, the Canadians have done, obviously very serious consideration would have been given to it, but the purpose of this legislation is to assist the exporters. As the Minister said in his opening words,, this measure is designed to promote Australian export trade. The honorable member for Lalor (Mr. Pollard) gave me the impression - I feel certain that most honorable members would have gained the same impression as I did - that he wanted the establishment of a corporation which could engage in all manner of insurance - the thin end of the wedge to bring about the complete plan of socialization of insurance which has been mentioned in this Parliament time and time again.

I am reminded that some years ago in this Parliament members of the Australian Labour party said that they were interested in everything except rag shops and ice-cream carts. To-night we have other evidence of that in the words of the honorable member for Lalor. He went further to say that the Government had introduced a bag of bones with no meat on it - a mere skeleton, and that it would therefore bring no profit to this country. I have never heard such utter rot from any member of any party, let alone the honorable member for Lalor, a member of the Australian Labour party of the present day, because if any measure is designed to increase our export trade it must obviously do some good for the whole of the Australian community. If members of the Australian Labour party would stop to realize just what it means to this country to improve our export trade, I am certain that they would not agree with the words of the honorable member for Lalor. They come to this Parliament with the idea, as they often express it, of representing the workers.

Does the honorable member, and do those who sit behind him, not realize that any increase in our export trade must obviously benefit a great number of those persons whom they claim to represent in this Parliament? To hear such words coming from the man who is leading in this debate for the Opposition shows very clearly that if Labour has this viewpoint it has completely missed the point. During his contribution we heard him discussing the export of 100,000,000 bushels of wheat to some unspecified country. Coming from an honorable member who formerly was Minister for Commerce and Agriculture in this country, that is somewhat astounding, as by and large the bulk of our exportable surplus of wheat is about 100,000,000 bushels. I have yet to hear that we have ever exported the whole of our surplus wheat to any one country or that we are ever likely to do so. For the honorable gentleman to base his argument on the export of 100,000,000 bushels of wheat, which would account for the £25,000,000 of insurance which this corporation is permitted to write, shows that he is scratching very hard for material with which to bolster his case.

Finally, I should like to say something else about the comments of the honorable member for Lalor. He gloried in the fact that the bill provides, he said, Tor ministerial control. It is very obvious that the honorable gentleman did not read the bill. Clause 11 does provide that the Minister and the members of the corporation shall get together to hammer out policy, and that if there is a disagreement they shall try to reach agreement, but if in the final analysis agreement is impossible the Minister shall lay down the policy. As he is the responsible member of Cabinet, responsible to Cabinet for the operation of this particular piece of machinery, that is right and proper The honorable member for Lalor indicated that the Minister had almost complete T>ower. yet clause 11 f4.) says quite definitely -

quote.para: Nothing in this section shall be construed us wiring the approval of the Minister to (b> entering bv the Corporation into a pArticular contract of insurance or aa empowering *hi> Minister to- determine that the Corporation shall or shall not enter into n particular contract of insurance. . . .

speech.para: That provision definitely prevents the Minister from exercising his authority and telling the corporation that it shall or shall not enter into certain types of insurance. That shows, further, that the honorable member who is leading for the Labour party did not even take thetrouble to read the Minister's second-reading speech, because at page 5 of the roneo-ed copy of the Minister's speech he used almost the same wordsas appear in the bill. He said -

quote.para: I also invite the attention of honorable members to the express provision in clauseU (4.) of the bill that the approval of the Minister is not required in relation to any particular insurance contract, nor is he empowered to determine that the corporation shall or shall not enter into any particular insurance contract.

speech.para: The contribution of the honorable member for Labour was very clearly and blatantly an advocacy for government insurance. The honorable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr. Crean) then entered the arena. He said that this was a hotch-potch -bill, suddenly brought in to correct our balance of trade, which had been thrown into discord by the vacillating policy of this Government. I feel certain that that same honorable gentleman knows only too well that this matter is not the result of some sudden inspiration of the Government but has been under its very serious consideration for some considerable time and that rather than introduce a hotch-potch piece of legislation the Government investigated this matter considerably and thoroughly. The honorable member continued by saying that there is no evidence of any languishingof this country's export trade. If that is the opinion of the Australian Labour party, it is obvious that its members have not been watching the trends of our economic position over the past eighteen monthsor so, nor have they studied any of the reports of exporting manufacturers and other persons whose very livelihood' depends, in the first instance, on their being able to export their products. Even in the Minister's second-reading speech, reference was made to that matter. The Minister said -

quote.para: For some time past the Government has received representations from ^Australian exporters and manufacturers who have claimed! that export payments insurance would greatly help them in building up export trade.

speech.para: This is a matter which, I repeat, has been causing the Government some concern for some considerable time, and I am very pleased to know that at long last it has been dealt with in this bill, which will at least do something to improve the export trade and help those manufacturers and primary producers who at present are finding it most difficult, because of certain problems, to export their goods. I certainly hope that this legislation will help manufacturing and secondary industries in the export trade, because statistics show that 96 per cent, of our overseas balances - if my memory serves me correctly, but the figure may be 94 per cent - are brought about by the export of our primary products, and only 4 per cent. - are brought about by the export secondary products. We have heard much from the Australian Labour party about the bill not going far enough, that it has Jio teeth in it. We are referred to Part II. of the Canadian Act of 1944, wherein the Governor in Council is empowered to make loans to the importing country to -enable it to purchase from the exporter the goods it requires. The last speaker referred to the countries immediately to our north, and told us how they needed goods and services, including machinery, that are available here. I remind honorable members opposite that for some time the Government has been doing exactly what they are now advocating: it has been making goods and services available to the Asian people to the north of this country. Strangely enough, the greatest critics of any attempt to develop our trade in Asia are the members of the Australian Labour party. Honorable members will recall bow vehemently they opposed the introduction of the Colombo plan, to which this Government has now been contributing for some years. The Labour party endeavoured to tear to shreds a proposal in one particular year to pay £S,000,000 toward the fund. They suggested that the money could be better spent in Australia.

talk.start.para: - The honorable member is no doubt referring to former members of the Labour party.

- The honorable member for Yarra (Mr. Cairns) is in this Parliament as a result of an accident of politics. But for a domesticproblem within the Labour party he would still be working somewhere in Melbourne. He defeated a prominent former member of his party. If he had been here when the Colombo plan was put forward by the then Minister for External Affairs, now Sir Percy Spender, he would no doubt have ardently supported his Labour colleagues' opposition to it. If it were possible for this country to embark upon a programme such as has been undertaken by the Canadian people it might be a very good idea to do so, but why have not Labour supporters given us evidence of the amounts that have been lent by that Government of Canada to other countries, or how much has been given by way of goods and services? The last speaker was alone in giving examples of the advancing of money or goods and services to other countries. He mentioned the Export and Import Bank of Washington, and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, which lent money to India for the building of canals, electrical installations and so on. One is tempted to believe that the action of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics was prompted by a desire, not to benefit the Indian people, but to get them within its grip and subsequently exercise control over them.

speech.para: This is the first bill of its kind to be introduced into this Parliament. It has been brought down at the request of people who are more concerned with Australia's future than is the Labour party. One Labour supporter called the bill a bag of bones that contained no meat. Another said that it was a hotch-potch that had resulted from the vacillating policy of the Government and the adverse balance of trade. If this represents the real attitude of the Labour party, it is obvious that Part II. of the Canadian legislation has been dragged in in an attempt to create as much confusion as possible. The bill before us does exactly the same, in the first instance, as does the Canadian legislation. As the Minister said, it is intended to " promote Australian export trade ". Clause 14 of the bill states -

quote.para: The Corporation shall -

item.label: (a)
item.para: endeavour to encourage trade with countries outside Australia by developing and expanding its business ; and

item.label: (b)
item.para: pursue a policy directed towards securing revenue sufficient to meet all its expenditure properly chargeable to revenue.

speech.para: I direct the attention of honorable members to the word "shall". Throughout the bill reference is made to the corporation's task of increasing Australia's export trade.

talk.start.para: - The vine fruit growers will be glad to hear that.

- We will export their product, and sell all our wheat as well. If the honorable member for Macquarie (Mr. Luchetti) can produce in Bathurst something that can be exported and will help our balance of payments we shall get along much better. This is Australia's first intrusion into this field, and it is being made in an attempt to increase our trade. Unless Labour supporters try to make the plan work - and I feel that it will work - those whom they claim to represent so ardently may soon be suffering.

speech.para: Mr.Calwell. - Is the bill not socialistic in character?

talk.start.para: - The honorable member for Melbourne (Mr.Calwell) asks whether the bill is socialistic in character. Unfortunately, he and his colleagues are still at the " wailing wall ". The Canadian legislation was introduced in 1944-45, when the Labour party was in office in this country, and when its members were talking about the coming "golden age". Surely, if they had had any business acumen, they would have brought in a similar bill. Instead, they preferred to ride on the crest of the wave and not worry about the future. No one can deny that the bill is an honest attempt to correct a position that has been evident for some time now. ' The Government, instead of bringing in a hotch-potch bill of the kind described by the honorable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr. Crean), first considered the matter seriously.

speech.para: I am reminded of a visit, not so long ago, to Asia by a trade mission. One of the Asian governments wished to buy second-hand tractors from Western Australia for clearing work. Because of the financial position of both the importer and the government concerned, a possible contract was lost. If this bill had then been on the statute book, the contract could have been accepted. This would have helped the farmers of Asia and brought revenue to Australia from the sale of tractors and spare parts.

I shall not detain the House much longer. I merely wish to support this bill which is, I believe, a step in the right direction. I do not know what is behind the move by Labour party supporters to confuse the issues. They say that the present bill is no good. They have dragged in the Canadian act, but they have not produced one tittle of evidence to show what the Canadian people have done. They have cited only two countries. The first was the United States of America, which is the world's richest country, and is jacking up the economy of a dozen other countries. Then Labour supporters crossed the North Pole to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics which is trying to worm its way into the democratic countries, but is not succeeding as well as it hoped. All the time they are talking in that strain, their minds must be going back to the days when they bitterly opposed the introduction of the Colombo plan.

talk.start.para: - That is not true.

- The honorable member for Melbourne (Mr.Calwell) says that it is not true. If he would refer to some of the Hansard reports of the proceedings of this Parliament when the Colombo plan was introduced, he would see that the Labour party did oppose it.
- We supported it.

- I repeat that every time honorable members opposite had the opportunity to do so, they opposed it. Now, when this legislation is brought down to assist the exporter, they trot out the Canadian act in an endeavour to hold up the passage of this measure. I support the bill, and hope that it will be passed speedily.
