.- It gives me great pleasure to discuss this measure. I support the bill 'because it is good as far as it goes, but the Opposition has already made it clear in this debate that a measure of this kind should go much further than does the bill before us. The proposal that we have put forward would extend the scope of the bill into a much more useful field like that covered by the Canadian and British legislation. The need for legislation such as this is most evident from an examination of the export trade situation. New measures to assist the export trade are long overdue, because the Government has been too timid in this field, as it is in this measure. Present practices in connexion with the export trade in primary products are old-fashioned and outmoded. Certainly, new measures in this field are necessary. Because of the sufficiency of the Australian market, only a very small proportion of Australian manufacturers are concerned with the export market.

speech.para: Another factor which influences the Australian exporter is the extent to which companies manufacturing in Australia are subject to franchises or agreements which exclude them from the export market. I refer particularly to chemicals and to the motor car industry. in which the Australian product cannot enter into the foreign market because the Australian company is restricted by franchises and agreements with the parent company of which it is a subsidiary. So, for all these reasons, there is a great call for new measures in this field.

The criticism that the Opposition makes of the bill is that it does not go nearly far enough. It has been shown overseas that the most important thing needed in this field is the provision of long-term credit - something more than insurance. This bill does not touch that field at all. Let us compare the relative costs. The Commonwealth has already advanced £40,000,000 of £50,000,000 this year on wheat that has not been sold. When will it be sold? I suggest that, by the application of a small fraction of that £40,000,000 or £50,000,000 to the extension of credit for the export of wheat, a great deal of the surplus could be carried off the Australian market. But the honorable member for Canning (Mr. Hamilton) who has just resumed his seat, is not prepared to support measures of this kind to clear the Australian market of wheat. However, he did me the honour of devoting about five minutes of his time to answering my interjections. I thank him for his courtesy. I also thank the members of the Government for their attention to ray interjections. I remind them that my interjections were to the effect that the Canadian legislation did not prevent the entry of the Canadian corporation into the ordinary insurance field. That is not provided for specifically, but the legislation does not prevent it. In comparison, the situation here is that the Australian legislation, brought down by a doctrinaire private enterprise government, does prevent the projected Australian corporation from entering into that field. This legislation provides for only very limited measures. It provides for measures which are concerned with the risks of nonpayment arising out of matters like insolvency, failure to pay within a given period, a blockade of foreign exchange, the imposition of import controls overseas, war, rebellion, hostilities, revolution or other disturbances in the oversea country, or any other cause outside the control of the exporter and arising outside Australia. But . as the Minister pointed out in his second-reading speech, it does not extend to these two other most important fields - fields which the Minister acknowledged to be of great importance. He said that the main types of risks dealt with in this bill were associated with non-payment. He also referred to the difficulty of promoting sales on credit. In relation to this second most important, matter, the bill does almost nothing. The Minister stated that policies or contracts of insurance should help the exporter to advance his export operations where sales on credit were necessary. I suggest that the bill should extend to insurance against all risks in connexion with the contract or transaction insured - not to all forms of insurance. The honorable member for Fawkner (Mr. Howson) took considerable time to deal with this matter as though we were proposing to cover all sorts of insurance - to nationalize insurance, as he put it. "What we were concerned with was to provide in this bill means whereby an insurer who was insuring for a special risk could also insure, if he so desired, against other normal risks. This Government is so doctrinaire in its free-enterprise attitude that it will not permit such an extension of the scheme. The second kind of risk that the Government should cover by insurance is the provision of credit to exporters to enable them to offer long terms to overseas buyers. Obviously,, that could be done only at very great cost. But, as has been pointed out, in the British and Canadian schemes, precisely these things are provided. They became the substance of the legislation, not the ancillary insurance provisions with which this bill is concerned. As the honorable member for Melbourne PoTts (Mr. Crean) has said, this bill is a step in the right direction, but it is a very timid step, indeed. The British scheme provides for guarantees to persons carrying on business in the United Kingdom in connexion with the export of goods.

Another provision is that of guarantees for the purpose of rendering economic assistance to countries outside the United Kingdom that carry on business in the Dinted Kingdom as appears to the Board' of Trade to be in the national interest so to do. That is covered by section 2 of the United Kingdom bill. No such provision appears in this legislation. How important would it be and how valuable would it be if we could provide at this stage, when we are spending £40,000,000 or £50,000,000 in subsidizing wheatgrowers because their wheat cannot be sold or can be sold only on the open market, guarantee legislation of that sort in order to help in the disposal of wheat. One of my colleagues says that the Government has taken the wheat provision out of that act. The Government has taken only the insurance provision, and has left the substance of the act as though it was not aware of the substance.

When one turns to the exports credits insurance scheme in Canada, one finds that the Canadian corporation that has been set up under this legislation may insure the exporter against the kind of tosses envisaged in the bill now before us. Section 13 of the act relates to that matter and, as I pointed out before, there is no specific exception that the corporation shall not do ordinary insurance business. The corporation has not the power under the act specifically to do that although the Canadian act does not go so far as specifically to accept it.

The most important part of the Canadian bill comes next. Under section 23 of the Exports Credits Insurance Act 1944-1945 the Governor-in-Council may make loans to any person in another country to enable such person to pay the cost of Canadian-produced goods purchased from an exporter. In section 23 of that act is the substance of the legislation.

When one refers to the legislation that has been enacted in Sweden and in. Switzerland, one also finds the substance of the Canadian legislation appearing. Why does the Australian Government not attempt to introduce legislation of that sort ? What is the answer of the Government

talk.start.para: - This is a start.

- The Government always was slow in making a start and when it makes a start it takes such a short step in the direction in which it has started. This bill characterizes the Government's' policy towards inflation since 1949. The bill, as can be seen, represents a very short step in the narrowness of the ordinary commercial channels-
- Is the honorable member supporting the bill?

- Yes, I am supporting the bill in principle. However, the Opposition says that the bill does not go far enough. We shall submit several amendments which will specifically indicate to the Government the direction in which we think it should go. The need for this measure has been thoroughly demonstrated. We are concerned, in the export field, with excessive and, in some cases, unfair competition. That is the stagethat the world's trading economy has reached and there is no question that the difficulties will grow. It will not be easy for Australia or any other country to solve its economic problems by overcoming the difficulties of export trade and a short step in this direction which the Minister for Customs and Excise (Mr. Osborne) has j,U St called the first step is not likely to achieve very much.

speech.para: Alao, this measure does demonstrate the situation that has recently developed. We have been told on many occasions that there is a very limited field indeed for the operations of the Government in trade, in commerce and in industry. That ia the philosophy of the supporters of the present Government. But a new principle is raised in this measure. It is an interesting principle because it now appears that when risks are involved in the development of a new industry or in what the Minister for Trade (Mr. McEwen) called the developmental unit when referring to the Australian Whaling Commission or when it is a matter of excessive risks in the export trade, it is the Government which will have to enter into the discharge of those risks. For a long time we have heard from the Government supporters advocacy of the wonderful virtues of free enterprise in overcoming risks. Now we have a new principle to which the supporters of the

Government have become attached. That is to say, when there is a great risk to be overcome it is the Government, through a corporation, which will have to overcome this risk and not the free enterprise which Government supporters are supposed so proudly to defend. I welcome this development.

So this measure, presumably, establishes a new and important principle. It is a principle to which, I hope, the Government will become sufficiently well attached to retain this corporation when it becomes a success, and not dispose of it as it has the habit of disposing of government enterprises when they begin to make a substantial profit. It seems to me that we must carefully distinguish the characteristic features of this bill. "We must distinguish the principle involved - the need in these times of excessive competition in the export trade for the Government and its agencies to extend into that field to assist private enterprise, rightly and properly, to enter that field, because there is no more important problem to overcome than the problem of export trade. Not only can it contribute substantially to the standard of living of the people of all countries involved but it can contribute also to better relations between those countries.

I suggest that the corporation envisaged in this legislation may even go further and provide assistance to exporters to travel overseas in search of new markets. It might provide means for exporters to obtain publicity in new overseas markets. It might provide means to allow overseas importers to visit Australia and discover in what way Australia can provide their needs. In this way, perhaps, the corporation could extend under the authority provided in the bill, the powers which the Minister said that it would have when he stated that it could perform any function which arose in risk in any other course outside the control of the exporter and arising outside Australia. That interpretation may cover these points. When this is achieved the bill as at present drawn might be extended to a somewhat wider field than the narrow field of insuring risks of this so-called political nature.

Finally, it is clear that the bill could go a great deal further without any risk of cost to the Government nearly in proportion to the cost that it already has to bear in having to purchase wheat on the Australian market which will not easily be disposed of or which will not be disposed of at all. If the Government was sufficiently imaginative and prepared to tackle the problem, as it exists, this measure could provide a great deal in the way of a solution of the difficulty. So I distinguish between the principle of the measure, which I feel should be supported and the extent to which the principle is carried into effect and in this respect, I do not think that the measure can be supported. Unless it is intended that this development shall be taken further, the measure is by no means satisfactory at this stage.
Debate (on motion by Mr. Cleaver) adjourned.
